bibl.title: The Oldest Manuscript of the Four Gospels?
bibl.note: [1. Introduction: P. Paris Bibl. Nat., Suppl. Gr. 1120 = P4 (= van Haelst 403), P. Oxford Magdalen College Inv. Gr. 17 (ex 18) = P64 (= van Haelst 336 (2)), and P. Barc. Inv. 1 = P67 (= van Haelst 336 (1))]. - 2. The Script of the Fragments. - 3. The Identity of the Script of P4, P64 and P67. - 4. Reconstruction of the Oxford Leaf (P64). - 5. The End of Matthew. - 6. The Beginning of Luke. - 7. The Contents of the Manuscript. - 8. The Structure of the Manuscript. - 9. The Text. - 10. Provenance. - 11. The Date of the Fragments. - 12. The Significance of the Codex. - 13. Conclusion.
bibl.seg: SKEAT T.C., The Oldest Manuscript of the Four Gospels?

[1. Introduction: P. Paris Bibl. Nat., Suppl. Gr. 1120 = P4 (= van Haelst 403), P. Oxford Magdalen College Inv. Gr. 17 (ex 18) = P64 (= van Haelst 336 (2)), and P. Barc. Inv. 1 = P67 (= van Haelst 336 (1))]. - 2. The Script of the Fragments. - 3. The Identity of the Script of P4, P64 and P67. - 4. Reconstruction of the Oxford Leaf (P64). - 5. The End of Matthew. - 6. The Beginning of Luke. - 7. The Contents of the Manuscript. - 8. The Structure of the Manuscript. - 9. The Text. - 10. Provenance. - 11. The Date of the Fragments. - 12.
